questions.text: A 25 year old male born to parents in a consanguineous marriage presents with the complaint of difficulty in night vision. Fundus examination is as shown in the picture. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Retinitis pigmentosa, primary pigmentary retinal dystrophy is a hereditary disorder predominantly affecting the photoreceptor (rods more than the cones).

Inheritance of Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) may occur as:

  • Sporadic disorder (40-50%)
  • Inherited disorder
  • Autosomal dominant RP (adRP)
  • Autosomal recessive RP (arRP)
  • X-linked recessive (XLR)
  • Digenic inheritance is very rare

Symptoms include: Night blindness, delayed dark adaptation, loss of peripheral vision and complete loss of vision in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following cell types are not present within the optic nerve?
questions.solution: Microscopically, the optic nerve possesses oligodendrocytes, astrocytes and microglia, whereas true peripheral nerves possess Schwann cells, fibroblasts and macrophages.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be affected in an optic nerve lesion?
questions.solution:
Localization of a lesion producing visual disturbance to the optic nerve can almost always be made by careful clinical examination including visual acuity, colour vision, pupillary reactions, visual field and ophthalmoscopic appearance of the optic nerve head. Sometimes visual disturbance in diseases affecting the optic nerve may be more subtle and may affect aspects of visual function other than visual acuity such as loss of contrast sensitivity, diminished stereoacuity and decrease in brightness of objects.

Photo stress test is abnormal in retinal diseases involving macula.

choices.text: Reduction in size of physiologic cup

questions.text: Which of the following is the first clinical sign of IIH?
questions.solution:
• Signs vary but one of the first is a blurring of the margins of the optic disc.
  • The blurring starts at the upper and lower margins and extends around the nasal side, while the temporal margin is usually still visible and sharp.
  • The disc becomes hyperaemic and gradually, progressive oedema extends over the surface of the disc reducing the size of the physiological cup, blurring the temporal margin and spreading into the surrounding retina.
  • The disc swells, the veins become congested and turgescent; their pulsations may be absent even on applying pressure on the globe.

questions.text: Which visual field defect is most likely associated with Anterior Ischemic Optic Neuropathy?
questions.solution:
• Ischaemic optic neuropathy, producing an altitudinal field defect, has been recognized for many years as a complication of severe anaemia or after a massive haemorrhage.
  • Patients suffering from a neglected acute attack of angle-closure glaucoma are also likely to develop ischaemic neuropathy with subsequent optic atrophy.
  • Generally an inferior attitudinal field defect is seen as the superior half of the disc is more often affected.
  • Enlargement of the blind spot= optic nerve head lesions
  • Central scotoma= macular defects
  • Arcuate scotoma= nerve fibre bundle defects

questions.text: HSV stromal keratitis is driven by which mechanism?
questions.solution:
Stromal keratitis in HSV: The stroma may be implicated and a disciform keratitis (Fig. 12.13D), sometimes of considerable extent, may develop.

This is an immunological reaction resembling an Arthus reaction.

Types of Immune reactions:

  • Type 1: IgE mediated
  • Type-2: Anti-body mediated
  • Type 3/Arthus reaction: Immune complex mediated
  • Type 4: Cytotoxic cell mediated

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for development of the pathology depicted in the picture below except?
questions.solution:
Subconjunctival haemorrhage, also called subconjunctival ecchymosis, is due to the rupture of small vessels.

  • The condition, though unsightly, is trivial.
  • This can occur spontaneously in elderly people with fragile vessels or those with systolic hypertension or after local ocular trauma or eye surgery.
  • Very minute ecchymoses, or possibly thromboses, are seen in severe conjunctivitis; large extravasations accompany severe straining, especially in old people, such as on lifting heavy weights or vomiting.
  • They are not infrequently seen in children with whooping cough and may occur in scurvy, in blood diseases such as purpura or in malaria. Rickets is caused by Vit D deficiency, not a known risk factor for SCH.
  • It is self resolving in two to three weeks time. No treatment is required

questions.text: Which syndrome is associated with target sign?
questions.solution:
Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome:

  1. Characteristics:
    • PXS is characterized by the deposition of a fibrillar material.
    • This material accumulates in the anterior segment of the eye.
  2. Material Source:
    • The exact origin of this material is not precisely known.
    • It is believed to arise from multiple sources.
    • It is part of a generalized basement membrane disorder.
  3. Effects on Zonules:
    • The deposition of pseudoexfoliation material on the lens zonules can lead to zonular weakness.
  • Pigment Dispersion Syndrome(Option A): This eye condition involves the release of pigment from the iris, leading to pigment accumulation in the eye and potential complications like glaucoma.
  • UGH Syndrome (Uveitis-Glaucoma-Hyphema Syndrome) (Option C): UGH syndrome is characterized by inflammation in the eye (uveitis), elevated intraocular pressure (glaucoma), and bleeding in the anterior chamber (hyphema), often associated with intraocular lens implants.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome(Option D): A rare neurological disorder, it features facial port-wine birthmarks and can involve eye issues, including glaucoma, due to abnormal blood vessel development in the brain and eye.

The above given syndromes have an open angle, and narrowing of the anterior chamber angle is not typically observed in these syndromes.

questions.text: The reciprocal inhibition of antagonist muscle is explained by
questions.solution:
• Herrings Law Of equal Innervation-During any conjugate movements, equal and simultaneous innervation flows to pair of yoke muscles.
  • Sherrington's Law of reciprocal innervation-Increase in innervation and contraction of a muscle is associated with reciprocal decrease in innervation and relaxation of its antagonist.

questions.text: In squint Surgery, muscle resection leads to
questions.solution:
PRINCIPLES OF SQUINT SURGERY

The basic principle of squint surgery is weakening of the process stronger muscle and strengthening of the weaker muscle. The weakening and strengthening procedures are

Weakening Procedures:

  • Recession: The insertion of the muscle is moved posteriorly towards its origin.
  • Marginal myotomy
  • Myectomy: Muscle is severed from its insertion but not reattached

Strengthening Procedures:

  • Resection: Pull of muscle is enhanced by making it shorter
  • Tucking
  • Advancement: Muscle is disinserted and advanced closer to the limbus.

questions.text: The condition in which the refractive state of the two eyes shows a considerable difference is called
questions.solution:
ANISOMETROPIA

  • This is the condition in which the refractive state of the two eyes shows a considerable difference. A slight difference is very common but all varieties and degrees of anisometropia occur.
  • The condition may cause asthenopic symptoms.
  • In the lower grades there is usually binocular vision, although it is imperfect and the effort of fusion may produce symptoms of eye strain.
  • In the higher grades exceeding 2.5 D, this is impossible and vision is then uniocular.
  • In such cases there is some danger of the eye which is not used becoming amblyopic in young children and divergent.

questions.text: In WHO classification (1982) of Xerophthalmia, X2 stands for:
questions.solution:
WHO classification (1982)- The new xerophthalmia classification (modification of original 1976 classification) is as follows:

  • XN Night blindness
  • X1A Conjunctival xerosis
  • X1B Bitot's spots
  • X2 Corneal xerosis
  • X3A Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia affecting less than one-third corneal surface
  • X3B Corneal ulceration/keratomalacia affecting more than one-third corneal surface
  • XS Corneal scar due to xerophthalmia
  • XF Xerophthalmic fundus

questions.text: A patient with new onset ocular myasthenia gravis should have a chest CT scan done to look for what associated condition?
questions.solution:
• Thymoma may occur in up to 10% of patients with myasthenia gravis; consequently, a patient with new-onset myasthenia gravis should be evaluated for the existence of this tumor.
  • Thymectomy would be the appropriate treatment if a mass is diagnosed.
  • Grave's disease is seen in approximately 5% of these patients and can be diagnosed by an orbital CT scan in conjunction with a clinical examination.
  • An apical lung tumor could be associated with Horner's syndrome; however, this patient did not present with symptoms suggestive of this syndrome.
  • Also, there is no association between Horner's syndrome and myasthenia gravis.
  • Sarcoidosis would most likely present with infiltrative or fibrotic pulmonary changes seen on chest x-ray, splenomegaly, and lymph node infiltration.

questions.text: Congenital Microphthalmos can be seen in which of the following:
questions.solution:
A picture of Left eye microphthalmia

  • Measles: Ocular lesions are: catarrhal conjunctivitis, Kolpik's spots on conjunctiva, corneal ulceration, optic neuritis and retinitis.
  • Mumps: Ocular involvement may occur as conjunctivitis, keratitis, acute dacryoadenitis and uveitis.
  • Rubella: Ocular lesions seen in rubella(German measles) are congenital microphthalmos, cataract, glaucoma, chorioretinitis and optic atrophy.
  • Whooping cough: There may occur subconjunctival hemorrhages and rarely orbital hemorrhage leading to proptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a common sign of an orbital blowout fracture?
questions.solution:
• Numbness of the ipsilateral cheek, upper lip, and upper teeth is a classic finding of a blowout fracture.
  • This hypoesthesia is a result of edema or direct injury to the infraorbital nerve as it courses through the infraorbital canal in the vicinity of the fracture site.
  • Restrictive strabismus is present in 40% to 63% of patients with isolated floor fractures. Enophthalmos may be present immediately or may develop later; it can be quantified by using an exophthalmometer.
  • Acute enophthalmos is due to loss of orbital tissue into the maxillary or ethmoid sinus. Late-onset enophthalmos results from atrophy and/or contraction of orbital tissues.
  • Other signs that suggest enophthalmos are a deepening of the superior sulcus or a narrowed palpebral fissure.
  • Tenderness over the zygomaticofrontal suture is not characteristic of an isolated blowout fracture but is a common finding in a zygomaticomaxillary (tripod) fracture.

questions.text: Anterior uveitis can occur in which of the following diseases?
Which of the following is true about sympathetic ophthalmitis?
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a serious bilateral granulomatous(non-suppurative) panuveitis which follows a penetrating ocular trauma.

The injured eye is called exciting eye and the fellow eye which also develops uveitis is called sympathizing eye.

Very rarely, sympathetic ophthalmitis can also occur following an intraocular surgery.

Pathology:

  • The primary inflammatory mediators are thought to be T cells(initial wave of infiltrative cells is composed of CD4+ helper T cells and a later wave of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells) that invade the uveal tract.
  • The inflammation is usually granulomatous and the choroid is diffusely thickened with lymphocytes, nests of epithelioid cells and multinucleated giant cells. The epithelioid cells and giant cells often contain melanin pigment.
  • The inflammatory process does not usually involve the choriocapillaris(in contrast to Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome) or the retina.
  • Dalen-Fuchs nodules, which are clusters of epithelioid cells containing pigment, lying between the retinal pigment epithelium and Bruch membrane, are also seen.
  • Anteriorly, the iris can appear thickened with nodular infiltrations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as local injection for ophthalmic use?
questions.solution:
All of the following are examples of steroids.

Methylprednisolone is administered only systemically.

The remaining steroids can be administered locally or systemically.

questions.text: Identify the ocular pathology
questions.solution:
The image shows out turning of the eyelid(Ectropion).

Inward turning of the eyelid is called entropion.

Eyelashes misdirected against ocular surface, with normal position of lid margin is called trichiasis.

Madarosis is the loss of eyelashes or eyebrows.

choices.text: Relative afferent pupillary defect is the first sign

questions.text: What is true about optic neuritis?
questions.solution:
Optic neuritis describes any condition that causes inflammation of the optic nerve; it may be associated with demyelinating diseases, or infectious or inflammatory processes.

It is also known as optic papillitis (when the head of the optic nerve is involved), neuroretinitis (when there is a combined involvement of the optic disc and surrounding retina in the macular area) and retrobulbar neuritis (when the posterior part of the nerve is involved). Prelaminar optic neuritis describes involvement of the non-myelinated axons in the retina. It is most often associated with multiple sclerosis, and it may lead to complete or partial loss of vision in one or both eyes. Other causes include:

Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy

Parainfectious optic neuritis (associated with viral infections such as measles, mumps, chickenpox, whooping cough and glandular fever)

Infectious optic neuritis (sinus related or associated with cat-scratch fever, tuberculosis, Lyme disease and cryptococcal meningitis in AIDS patients

Autoimmune causes (sarcoidosis, systemic lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, MOG antibody disease, granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

Diabetes mellitus

Low phosphorus levels

Hyperkalaemia

Signs and symptoms

Example of how optic neuritis affected one eye of a person with multiple sclerosis

Major symptoms are sudden loss of vision (partial or complete), sudden blurred or "foggy" vision, and pain on movement of the affected eye. Early symptoms that require investigation include symptoms from multiple sclerosis (twitching, lack of coordination, slurred speech, frequent episodes of partial vision loss or blurred vision), episodes of "disturbed/blackened" rather than blurry indicate moderate stage and require immediate medical attention to prevent further loss of vision. Other early symptoms are reduced night vision, photophobia and red eyes. Many patients with optic neuritis may lose some of their color vision in the affected eye (especially red), with colors appearing subtly washed out compared to the other eye. Patients may also experience difficulties judging movement in depth, which can be particular troublesome during driving or sport (Pulfrich effect). Likewise, transient worsening of vision with increase of body temperature (Uhthoff's phenomenon) and glare disability are a frequent complaint. However, several case studies in children have demonstrated the absence of pain in more than half of cases (approximately 60%) in their pediatric study population, with the most common symptom reported simply as "blurriness". Other remarkable differences between the presentation of adult optic neuritis as compared to pediatric cases include more often unilateral optic neuritis in adults, while children much predominantly present with bilateral involvement.

On medical examination the head of the optic nerve can easily be visualized by a slit lamp with a high positive lens or by using direct ophthalmoscopy; however, frequently there is no abnormal appearance of the nerve head in optic neuritis (in cases of retrobulbar optic neuritis), though it may be swollen in some patients (anterior papillitis or more extensive optic neuritis). In many cases, only one eye is affected, and patients may not be aware of the loss of color vision until they are asked to close or cover the healthy eye.

Cause

The optic nerve comprises axons that emerge from the retina of the eye and carry visual information to the primary visual nuclei, most of which is relayed to the occipital cortex of the brain to be processed into vision. Inflammation of the optic nerve causes loss of vision, usually because of the swelling and destruction of the myelin sheath covering the optic nerve.

The most common cause is multiple sclerosis (MS) or ischemic optic neuropathy due to thrombosis or embolism of the vessel that supplies the optic nerve. Up to 50% of patients with MS will develop an episode of optic neuritis, and 20-30% of the time optic neuritis is the presenting sign of MS.[citation needed] The presence of demyelinating white matter lesions on brain MRI at the time of presentation of optic neuritis is the strongest predictor for developing clinically definite MS. Almost half of the patients with optic neuritis have white matter lesions consistent with multiple sclerosis.

Some other common causes of optic neuritis include infection (e.g. a tooth abscess in the upper jaw, syphilis, Lyme disease, herpes zoster), autoimmune disorders (e.g. lupus, neurosarcoidosis, neuromyelitis optica), methanol poisoning, vitamin B12 deficiency, beriberi, dysautonomia (i.e. autonomic nervous system dysfunction), and diabetes, or an injury to the eye. In neuromyelitis optica higher AQP4 autoantibody levels are associated with the occurrence of optic neuritis.

Less common causes are: papilledema, brain tumor or abscess in the occipital region, cerebral trauma or hemorrhage, meningitis, arachnoidal adhesions, sinus thrombosis, liver dysfunction, or late stage kidney disease.

Treatment

In most MS-associated optic neuritis, visual function spontaneously improves over 2-3 months, and there is evidence that corticosteroid treatment does not affect the long term outcome. However, for optic neuritis that is not MS-associated (or atypical optic neuritis) the evidence is less clear and therefore the threshold for treatment with intravenous corticosteroids is lower. Intravenous corticosteroids also reduce the risk of developing MS in the following two years in patients with MRI lesions; but this effect disappears by the third year of follow up.

Paradoxically, oral administration of corticosteroids in this situation may lead to more recurrent attacks than in non-treated patients (though oral steroids are generally prescribed after the intravenous course, to wean the patient off the medication). This effect of corticosteroids seems to be limited to optic neuritis and has not been observed in other diseases treated with corticosteroids.

A Cochrane systematic review studied the effect of corticosteroids for treating people with acute optic neuritis. Specific corticosteroids studied included intravenous and oral methylprednisone, and oral prednisone. The authors conclude that current evidence does not show a benefit of either intravenous or oral corticosteroids for rate of recovery of vision (in terms of visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, or visual fields). There are a number of reasons why this might be the case.

Option A: Multiple Myeloma is the cause

  • Optic neuritis is commonly associated with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), infections, autoimmune diseases (e.g., lupus, sarcoidosis), and vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Multiple myeloma is NOT a direct cause of optic neuritis.

Option C: Painless

  • One of the hallmark symptoms of optic neuritis is pain, especially during eye movements.
  • Painless vision loss is more common in conditions like ischemic optic neuropathy.

Option D: Oral Steroids is DOC

  • Intravenous (IV) corticosteroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are preferred for treatment.
  • Oral steroids alone may actually increase the risk of recurrent optic neuritis, as shown in the ONTT (Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial).
  • Oral steroids may be used after IV therapy for tapering but are not the first-line treatment.

Key Takeaway:

  • RAPD is the earliest clinical sign of optic neuritis
  • Optic neuritis is often associated with MS, NOT multiple myeloma
  • Optic neuritis is painful, NOT painless
  • IV steroids (not oral) are the preferred treatment

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optic_neuritis

questions.text: What would be the investigation for bilateral proptosis and chloroma in a child?
questions.solution:
Blood film in leukaemias. (A) Bone marrow aspirate in acute myeloid leukaemia showing immature blast cells; (B) peripheral blood smear in chronic lymphatic leukaemia showing many mature lymphocytes

Leukaemia Introduction

The leukaemias are malignancies of haematopoietic stem cells involving abnormal proliferation of white blood cells. Acute leukaemia is characterized by the replacement of bone marrow with immature (blast) cells. Chronic leukaemia is associated, at least initially, with well-differentiated (mature) leukocytes and occurs almost exclusively in adults. The four major variants of leukaemia are:

  • Acute lymphocytic (lymphoblastic) predominantly affects children, in whom there is around a 90% 5-year survival rate.
  • Acute myeloid (myeloblastic) is most frequently seen in older adults.
  • Chronic lymphocytic has a very chronic course and many patients die from unrelated disease.
  • Chronic myelocytic has a progressive clinical course and often a less favourable prognosis.

Ocular features

Ocular involvement is more commonly seen in the acute than the chronic forms and virtually any ocular structure may be involved.

Primary leukaemic infiltration is fairly rare. Secondary changes such as those associated with anaemia, thrombocytopenia, hyperviscosity and opportunistic infections are more common and include intraocular bleeding, infection and vascular occlusion.

  • Fundus
    • Retinal haemorrhages and cotton-wool spots are common.
    • Roth spots are retinal haemorrhages with white centres, the whitish element is thought to be composed of coagulated fibrin in most cases. They occur in acute leukaemia and in a range of other conditions such as bacteraemia (classically subacute bacterial endocarditis), diabetes, hypertension and anaemia.
    • Peripheral retinal neovascularization is an occasional feature of chronic myeloid leukaemia.
    • Retinal and choroidal infiltrates may occur, most commonly posterior to the equator and may masquerade as posterior uveitis. In chronic leukaemia they may give rise to a 'leopard skin' appearance.
    • Scattered haemorrhages may occur in patients with thrombocytopenia.
    • Optic nerve infiltration may cause swelling and visual loss.
  • Other features
    • Orbital involvement, particularly in children
    • Iris thickening, iritis and pseudohypopyon Spontaneous subconjunctival haemorrhage and hyphaema.
    • Cranial nerve palsies.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

Option B: HB Estimation - While anemia is common in leukemia, HB estimation alone cannot diagnose leukemia or chloroma. A low HB might be present, but it does not provide specific information about leukemic cell infiltration.

Option C: Total Leucocyte Count - While leukocytosis or leukopenia can be seen in leukemia, TLC alone is not diagnostic. It does not differentiate between leukemia and other infections or hematological disorders.

Option D: Platelet Count - Leukemia often leads to thrombocytopenia, but a low platelet count does not confirm leukemia or chloroma. It is a secondary finding rather than a primary diagnostic tool.

Key Takeaway:

  • Peripheral blood smear is the first-line investigation in suspected leukemia cases.
  • Chloroma (myeloid sarcoma) is a rare extramedullary tumor seen in AML.
  • Bilateral proptosis in a child is a red flag for hematological malignancies.
  • Further bone marrow aspiration and biopsy confirm leukemia.

questions.text: 14 DAY NEONATE WITH BILATERAL CONJUNCTIVITIS X-ray showing infiltrates. which of the following is the most probable infection?
questions.solution:
Neonatal conjunctivitis is a form of conjunctivitis (inflammation of the outer eye) which affects newborn babies following birth. It is typically due to neonatal bacterial infection, although can also be non-infectious (e.g. chemical exposure). Infectious neonatal conjunctivitis is typically contracted during vaginal delivery from exposure to bacteria from the birth canal, most commonly Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis.

Antibiotic ointment is typically applied to the newborn's eyes within 1 hour of birth as prevention for gonococcal ophthalmia. This practice is recommended for all newborns and most hospitals in the United States are required by state law to apply eye drops or ointment soon after birth to prevent the disease.

If left untreated, neonatal conjunctivitis can cause blindness.

Signs and symptoms

Neonatal conjunctivitis by definition presents during the first month of life. Signs and symptoms include:[citation needed]

Pain and tenderness in the eyeball

Conjunctival discharge: purulent, mucoid or mucopurulent (depending on the cause)

Conjunctival hyperaemia and chemosis, usually also with swelling of the eyelids

Corneal involvement (rare) may occur in herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatorum

Time of onset

Chemical causes: Right after delivery

Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Delivery of the baby until 5 days after birth (early onset)

Chlamydia trachomatis: 5 days after birth to 2 weeks (late onset - C. trachomatis has a longer incubation period)

Complications

Untreated cases may develop corneal ulceration, which may perforate, resulting in corneal opacification and staphyloma formation.[citation needed]

Cause

Non-infectious

Chemical irritants such as silver nitrate can cause chemical conjunctivitis, usually lasting 2-4 days. Thus, prophylaxis with a 1% silver nitrate solution is no longer in common use. In most countries, neomycin and chloramphenicol eye drops are used, instead. However, newborns can develop neonatal conjunctivitis due to reactions with chemicals in these common eye drops. Additionally, a blocked tear duct may be another noninfectious cause of neonatal conjunctivitis.[citation needed]

Infectious

The two most common infectious causes of neonatal conjunctivitis are N. gonorrheae and Chlamydia, typically acquired from the birth canal during delivery. However, other different bacteria and viruses can be the cause, including herpes simplex virus (HSV 2), Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.[citation needed]

Ophthalmia neonatorum due to gonococci (N. gonorrhoeae) typically manifests in the first 5 days after birth and is associated with marked bilateral purulent discharge and local inflammation. In contrast, conjunctivitis secondary to infection with C. trachomatis produces conjunctivitis 3 days to 2 weeks after delivery. The discharge is usually more watery in nature (mucopurulent) and less inflamed. Babies infected with chlamydia may develop pneumonitis (chest infection) at a later stage (range 2-19 weeks after delivery). Infants with chlamydia pneumonitis should be treated with oral erythromycin for 10-14 days.

Diagnosis is performed after taking swab from the infected conjunctivae

Prophylaxis needs antenatal, natal, and postnatal care.

Antenatal measures include thorough care of mother and treatment of genital infections when suspected.

Natal measures are of utmost importance, as most infection occurs during childbirth. Deliveries should be conducted under hygienic conditions taking all aseptic measures. The newborn baby's closed lids should be thoroughly cleansed and dried.

If the cause is determined to be due to a blocked tear duct, gentle palpation between the eye and the nasal cavity may be used to clear the tear duct. If the tear duct is not cleared by the time the newborn is 1 year old, surgery may be required.

Postnatal measures include:

Use of 1% tetracycline ointment, 0.5% erythromycin ointment, or 1% silver nitrate solution (Crede's method) into the eyes of babies immediately after birth

Single injection of ceftriaxone IM or IV should be given to infants born to mothers with untreated gonococcal infection.

Curative treatment as a rule, conjunctival cytology samples and culture sensitivity swabs should be taken before starting treatment.

Chemical ophthalmia neonatorum is a self-limiting condition and does not require any treatment.

Gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum needs prompt treatment to prevent complications. Topical therapy should include:

Saline lavage hourly until the discharge is eliminated

Bacitracin eye ointment four times per day (because of resistant strains, topical penicillin therapy is not reliable, but in cases with proven penicillin susceptibility, penicillin drops 5000 to 10000 units per ml should be instilled every minute for half an hour, every five minutes for next half an hour, and then half-hourly until the infection is controlled.)

If the cornea is involved, then atropine sulfate ointment should be applied.

The advice of both the pediatrician and ophthalmologist should be sought for proper management.

Systemic therapy: Newborns with gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum should be treated for 7 days with ceftriaxone, cefotaxime, ciprofloxacin, or crystalline benzyl penicillin.

Other bacterial ophthalmia neonatorum should be treated by broad-spectrum antibiotics drops and ointment for 2 weeks.

Neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by C. trachomatis should be treated with oral erythromycin. Topical therapy is not effective and also does not treat the infection of the nasopharynx.

Herpes simplex conjunctivitis should be treated with intravenous acyclovir for a minimum of 14 days to prevent systemic infection.

Incorrect Options Explanation

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae - While H. influenzae can cause conjunctivitis and respiratory infections, it is not a common cause of neonatal conjunctivitis. It is more frequently associated with childhood conjunctivitis rather than infections in neonates.

Option C: Streptococcus - Group B Streptococcus (GBS) can cause neonatal pneumonia and sepsis, but it is a rare cause of neonatal conjunctivitis. It usually presents with severe systemic infections rather than isolated conjunctivitis.

Option D: Mycoplasma - Mycoplasma pneumoniae is not a typical cause of neonatal conjunctivitis. It is more commonly associated with atypical pneumonia in older children and adults rather than neonates.

Key Takeaway

Chlamydia trachomatis is a leading cause of neonatal conjunctivitis, especially when symptoms appear after 5 days of birth. It can be associated with pneumonitis, leading to X-ray infiltrates, making it the most probable infection in this case. Oral erythromycin is the treatment of choice.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neonatal_conjunctivitis

choices.text: 1- Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 - Outer nuclear layer, 3 - Inner plexiform layer, 4 - Ganglion layer
1- Retinal Pigment Epithelium, 2 - Inner nuclear layer, 3 - Outer plexiform layer, 4 - Ganglion layer
1- Ganglion layer, 2 - Inner nuclear layer, 3 - Outer plexiform layer, 4 - Retinal Pigment Epithelium
1- Ganglion layer, 2 - Outer plexiform layer, 3 - Inner nuclear layer, 4 - Retinal Pigment Epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the retina are marked correctly?
questions.solution:
Microscopic Structure of the Retina:

The retina has 10 layers, divided into two parts: the pigment epithelium and the neurosensory retina, with a potential space in between.

  1. Pigment Epithelium: Outer layer of the retina, consisting of a single layer of pigment cells. It supports the neurosensory retina and acts as an antireflective layer. The interphotoreceptor matrix (IPM) binds the two layers.
  2. Rods and Cones: Photoreceptor cells for vision. Rods are responsible for peripheral and low-light vision, while cones are responsible for central, color, and high-resolution vision.
  3. External Limiting Membrane: A membrane allowing the passage of rod and cone processes.
  4. Outer Nuclear Layer: Contains the nuclei of rods and cones.
  5. Outer Plexiform Layer: Contains synapses between rods, cones, bipolar cells, and horizontal cells.
  6. Inner Nuclear Layer: Contains bipolar, horizontal, amacrine, and Muller's cell bodies, as well as capillaries of the central retinal artery.
  7. Inner Plexiform Layer: Contains synapses between bipolar cell axons, ganglion cell dendrites, and amacrine cells.
  8. Ganglion Cell Layer: Contains ganglion cell bodies, which are second-order neurons. Two types exist: midget ganglion cells (macula region) and polysynaptic ganglion cells (peripheral retina).
  9. Nerve Fibre Layer: Made up of axons from ganglion cells, forming the optic nerve.
  10. Internal Limiting Membrane: The innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous, formed by Muller's cell expansions.

Fovea Centralis:

  • Contains tightly packed cones; rods are absent.
  • The central part (foveola) consists mostly of cone nuclei, with other retinal layers absent.

Functional Divisions:

  • The retina is divided into temporal and nasal regions.
  • Nerve fibres from the temporal retina go to the same side's geniculate body, while those from the nasal retina cross at the optic chiasm and reach the opposite geniculate body.
  • The geniculate body neurons are the third-order neurons in the visual pathway.

Reference: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41433-021-01437-w

questions.text: In the case of Best disease, which of the following is the diagnostic investigation?
questions.solution:
Best Disease (Vitelliform Dystrophy of the Fovea)

Best disease is characterized by a sharply defined, usually bilateral, orange-yellow disc in the foveal region that resembles the yolk of a fried egg. Visual acuity typically remains good, and the neuroepithelium remains unaffected initially. Vision loss occurs when the lesion transitions into an irregular pigmented area, becomes "scrambled," or experiences hemorrhages, leading to polymorphous foveal dystrophy.

The vitelliform disc is believed to be located in the pigment epithelium and contains viscous, homogeneous material.

Clinical Features

  • Visual Fields: Normal except for a central scotoma.
  • Dark Adaptation & Electroretinogram (ERG): Both remain normal.
  • Electrooculogram (EOG): Pathological

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: ERG (Electroretinogram) (Incorrect)

  • ERG is normal in Best disease, as photoreceptor function remains intact in early stages.
  • ERG is useful in conditions like Retinitis Pigmentosa, but not in diagnosing Best disease.

Choice C: Visual Evoked Potential (Incorrect)

  • VEP assesses optic nerve function and is used for conditions like optic neuritis or demyelinating diseases (e.g., multiple sclerosis).
  • It has no role in diagnosing Best disease, which is a retinal disorder.

Choice D: Multifocal ERG (Incorrect)

  • Multifocal ERG helps evaluate localized retinal dysfunction but is not a primary diagnostic tool for Best disease.
  • EOG remains the gold standard for diagnosis.

Key Takeaway:

Best disease is diagnosed using EOG, which shows a reduced Arden ratio, while ERG remains normal.

questions.text: Patient undergoes lens implantation. There is worsening of vision after 1 year of lens implantation. Slit lamp examination is done and finding is shown on the image. Identify the complication
questions.solution:
After Cataract (Secondary Cataract)

Definition:

After cataract, also known as secondary cataract, is the opacity that develops or persists after extracapsular lens extraction.

Causes:

  1. Residual Opaque Lens Matter:
    • May persist when it is trapped between the anterior and posterior lens capsule, surrounded by fibrin (due to iritis) or blood (due to hyphaema).
  2. Proliferative After Cataract:
    • Develops from leftover anterior epithelial cells in the capsular bag. These cells proliferate and form hyaline bands that can sweep across the posterior capsule.

Clinical Types:

  1. Thickened Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO):
    • A common form of after cataract.
  2. Dense Membranous After Cataract:
    • A dense membrane forms on the posterior capsule.
  3. Soemmering's Ring:
    • A thick ring of after cataract forms behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of the capsule.
  4. Elschnig's Pearls:
    • Clusters of vacuolated epithelial cells (resembling soap bubbles) appear on the posterior capsule.

Treatment:

  1. Thin Membranous After Cataract & PCO:
    • Treated with YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission using a cystitome or Zeigler's knife.
  2. Dense Membranous After Cataract:
    • Requires surgical membranectomy.
  3. Soemmering's Ring:
    • If the central posterior capsule is clean, no treatment is needed.
  4. Elschnig's Pearls:
    • Central involvement can be treated with YAG-laser capsulotomy or discission with a cystitome.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Bullous Keratopathy

  • Corneal endothelial decompensation leading to corneal edema and bullae formation.
  • Presents with pain, photophobia, and blurred vision due to epithelial edema, not posterior capsule opacification.
  • Slit-lamp examination would show corneal edema and microcystic changes, not posterior capsule changes.

Choice C: Subluxation of Lens

  • Partial displacement of the intraocular lens (IOL) due to zonular weakness or trauma.
  • Symptoms include monocular diplopia and significant refractive changes.
  • Slit-lamp examination would reveal decentration of the lens, which is not seen in PCO.

Choice D: Corneal Opacity

  • A result of corneal scarring or infection, leading to permanent visual impairment.
  • Slit-lamp examination would show hazy or white areas in the cornea, rather than posterior capsular changes.

Key Takeaway

Posterior Capsular Opacification is the correct diagnosis, as it presents with gradual blurring of vision months to years after cataract surgery, and slit-lamp examination confirms posterior capsule haze or Elschnig's pearls. The preferred treatment is YAG-laser capsulotomy.

Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capsulotomy

questions.text: The muscle responsible for ptosis in Horner's syndrome is?
questions.solution:
Horner's Syndrome

Horner's Syndrome occurs due to oculo-sympathetic paresis and is characterized by the classic triad:

  1. Mild Ptosis: Caused by paralysis of Muller's muscles.
  2. Miosis: Constriction of the pupil due to paralysis of the dilator pupillae.
  3. Anhidrosis: Reduced sweating on the ipsilateral side of the face.

Other Features:

  • Mild enophthalmos: Slight sinking of the eyeball.
  • Loss of the cilio-spinal reflex.
  • Heterochromia: The ipsilateral iris may appear lighter in color.
  • Delayed pupil dilation.
  • Slight elevation of the lower eyelid.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Levator Palpebrae Superioris (LPS)

  • LPS is the primary muscle responsible for eyelid elevation.
  • It is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (CN III), not the sympathetic system.
  • Damage to LPS (CN III palsy) causes complete ptosis, unlike the mild ptosis seen in Horner's syndrome.

Choice C: Orbicularis Oculi

  • Function: Closes the eyelid.
  • Innervation: Facial nerve (CN VII).
  • Lesions affecting this muscle cause incomplete eyelid closure (lagophthalmos), not ptosis.

Choice D: Horner's Muscle

  • Horner's muscle is part of the lacrimal pump mechanism, not related to ptosis.
  • It is a portion of the orbicularis oculi that helps drain tears into the lacrimal sac.

Key Takeaway

Muller's Muscle is correct because its sympathetic innervation is disrupted in Horner's syndrome, leading to mild ptosis.

questions.text: A visual field defect image is given, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hemianopia refers to the loss of half of the field of vision in one or both eyes. The most common form is homonymous hemianopia, where one half of the visual field is lost in both eyes. This can be caused by a lesion anywhere along the visual pathways, from the chiasm to the occipital lobe. In this condition, a lesion will affect the corresponding halves of each retina, leading to loss of vision in the opposite halves of the visual fields.

  • Right homonymous hemianopia is often noticed quickly since it can interfere with tasks like reading.
  • Left homonymous hemianopia may go unnoticed until the patient fails to notice food on the left side of a plate, for instance.

Macular Sparing

In many cases, the macula (the central part of the retina responsible for detailed vision) remains unaffected, especially if the lesion is near the occipital cortex. This is likely because the macular fibres have a separate, segregated pathway in the optic radiations, and their representation in the occipital pole is supplied by both the posterior cerebral artery and the middle cerebral artery. These arteries rarely block simultaneously. This macular sparing may also be due to the functional shift of fixation towards the unaffected part of the retina.

Lesions in the Lateral Geniculate Body

Lesions in the lateral geniculate body (part of the thalamus that processes visual information) can result in homonymous hemianopia. However, lesions confined to thepulvinar or superior colliculus do not cause this condition.

Lesions of the Optic Tract

Lesions of the optic tract lead to homonymous hemianopia, where one side of the visual field is lost in both eyes. Since the afferent pupillary fibres (responsible for pupil response) separate from the visual fibres before entering the lateral geniculate body, a Wernicke hemianopic pupil reaction should be present. However, this reaction is often difficult to elicit due to its subtle nature.

Key Diagnostic Features

  • Collateral Symptoms: The diagnosis of optic tract lesions is often assisted by other neurological symptoms due to the optic tract's proximity to critical structures like the crus cerebri (part of the brainstem), the third cranial nerve, and other cranial nerves. For example:
    • Right homonymous hemianopia combined with left third nerve paralysis (oculomotor nerve) and right hemiplegia (paralysis on the right side of the body) suggests a lesion in the left optic tract.
  • Fixation Point: Unlike lesions closer to the geniculate body or visual cortex, the fixation point (central vision) typically does not escape in optic tract hemianopia.
  • Atrophy of Optic Nerves: In cases of chronic optic tract lesions, there may be partial atrophy (shrinkage) of both optic nerves, which becomes apparent through pallor of the optic discs (the point where the optic nerve enters the retina). If there is increased intracranial pressure,papilloedema (swelling of the optic disc) may precede optic atrophy.

Causes of Optic Tract Lesions

  1. Syphilitic Meningitis or Gumma: These infections can cause lesions in the optic tract, often as part of tertiary syphilis.
  2. Tuberculosis: This can affect the optic tract, especially when it involves structures like the optic thalamus or temporosphenoidal lobe.
  3. Tumors: Tumors of the optic thalamus, temporosphenoidal lobe, or even around the pituitary can lead to optic tract compression.
  4. Aneurysms: Aneurysms in the upper basilar distribution, or those in the superior cerebellar arteries or posterior cerebral arteries, are also common causes of compression or lesions in the optic tract.

Rare Causes

  • Softening and hemorrhage are rare causes of optic tract damage but can occur in certain circumstances.
  • Primary optic tract lesions are extremely rare, and when they do occur, they are typically the result of compression rather than direct damage.

Tract Hemianopia Characteristics

  • Incongruity: Hemianopia caused by lesions in the optic tract tends to be incongruous, meaning the visual field loss in each eye is asymmetrical, with some variations in the density or severity of the field loss between the two eyes.
  • Awareness: Patients with lesions above the geniculate body (such as in the occipital cortex) may be unaware of their visual defect, while those with lesions at or below the geniculate body (e.g., in the optic tract) are typicallyconscious of their hemianopic defect.

Optic Tract Hemianopia

When the optic tract is affected,hemianopia typically appears incongruent, meaning the visual field loss in each eye does not match in density or severity.

Diagnostic Considerations

  • The presence of partial atrophy in both optic nerves often accompanies optic tract lesions, with pallor of the discs. In cases with increased intracranial pressure, papilloedema (swelling of the optic disc) may also be seen.
  • Patients with lesions above the geniculate body may not immediately notice their visual defect, whereas those with lesions in or below the geniculate body tend to be more aware of their visual loss.


Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Bitemporal hemianopia
    • Affects both temporal (outer) visual fields, caused by an optic chiasm lesion (e.g., pituitary tumors).
    • The provided image does not show bitemporal involvement.
  • Choice B: Complete binasal hemianopia
    • Affects both nasal (inner) visual fields, usually due to bilateral lateral compression of the optic chiasm(e.g., bilateral internal carotid artery aneurysms).
    • Rare condition, not fitting the provided image.
  • Choice D: Altitudinal hemianopia
    • Causes upper or lower half vision loss, often due to vascular issues like anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION) or retinal artery occlusion.
    • The provided image shows a homonymous pattern, not an altitudinal defect.

Key Takeaway

Homonymous hemianopia is correct, as the image depicts loss of vision in the same side of the visual field in both eyes, typically due to lesions affecting the post-chiasmal visual pathway.

questions.text: An one month old baby comes with watering eyes and a cloudy cornea. Identify the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Buphthalmos (plural: buphthalmos) is enlargement of the eyeball and is most commonly seen in infants and young children. It is sometimes referred to as buphthalmia (plural buphthalmos). It usually appears in the newborn period or the first 3 months of life. and in most cases indicates the presence of congenital (infantile) glaucoma, which is a disorder in which elevated pressures within the eye lead to structural eye damage and vision loss.

Signs and symptoms

Buphthalmos in itself is merely a clinical sign and does not generate symptoms. Patients with glaucoma often initially have no symptoms; later, they can exhibit excessive tearing (lacrimation) and extreme sensitivity to light (photophobia). On ophthalmologic exam, a doctor can detect increased intraocular pressure, distortion of the optic disc, and corneal edema, which manifests as haziness.

Other symptoms include a prominent eyeball, Haab's striae tear in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea, an enlarged cornea, and myopia.

  • Congenital glaucoma (buphthalmos) is due to abnormal development of the trabecular meshwork, leading to elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Classic triad of symptoms:
    • Epiphora (excessive tearing)
    • Photophobia (light sensitivity)
    • Corneal clouding (edema)
  • Other signs: Enlarged cornea, Haab's striae (Descemet's membrane breaks), increased cup-to-disc ratio, and optic nerve damage.

Incorrect Options Explanation:

(A) Cataract: Would present with lens opacity and leukocoria, but not with tearing or corneal clouding.

(C) Ophthalmia Neonatorum: Neonatal conjunctivitis due to infection (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis), presents with purulent discharge and conjunctival redness, but not corneal clouding.

(D) Mucopolysaccharidosis: Can cause corneal clouding, but symptoms develop later in infancy or childhood, often with systemic manifestations (coarse facies, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal deformities).

Key Takeaway:

Congenital glaucoma presents in newborns with excessive tearing, photophobia, and a cloudy cornea. It must be diagnosed early to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Which anti-glaucoma drug causes ocular hypotension with apnoea in an infant?
questions.solution:
Brimonidine is a selective alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that lowers intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous humour production and increasing uveoscleral outflow. However, it can cross the blood-brain barrier, leading to central nervous system (CNS) depression in infants. Reported adverse effects include bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, hypotonia, and apnoea, making it contraindicated in neonates and infants.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • A. Latanoprost: A prostaglandin analog that primarily increases uveoscleral outflow to lower intraocular pressure. It does not have significant systemic absorption or CNS effects and is not associated with apnoea.
  • B. Timolol: A non-selective beta-blocker that reduces aqueous humour production. Though it can cause systemic side effects like bradycardia and respiratory depression, it is less likely to cause apnoea compared to brimonidine.
  • D. Dorzolamide: A topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that decreases aqueous humour production. While systemic absorption can cause metabolic acidosis, it is not known to cause apnoea in infants.

Key Takeaway:

Brimonidine should be avoided in infants due to the risk of CNS depression, which can lead to apnoea, hypotension, and bradycardia.

questions.text: The most common cause of proptosis in adults is:
questions.solution:
Preseptal cellulitis is an inflammation of the tissues localized anterior to the orbital septum. The orbital septum is a fibrous tissue that divides the orbit contents in two compartments: preseptal (anterior to the septum) and postseptal (posterior to the septum). The inflammation that develops posterior to the septum is known as "orbital cellulitis". Both entities are caused by an infectious process.

Etiology

The majority of these infections are caused by bacteria. Adenovirus, herpes simplex and varicella zoster are also associated to cellulitis. In the immunocompromised patient we must suspect fungi as a possible etiology. Gram positive cocci are the most prevalent microorganisms identified in preseptal cellulitis - typically Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species (pyogenes and pneumonia). Staphylococcus aureus and epidermidis are commonly found after a penetrating eyelid trauma. Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common etiology in preseptal cellulitis secondary to sinusitis. In the era before the establishment of the universal vaccination against Haemophilus influenza type b, this was a frequent etiology especially in children under 5 years of age. It is still common in unvaccinated patients. In preseptal cellulitis secondary to a human bite it is frequent to isolate anaerobic bacteria such as Clostridium.

Diagnosis

Patients complain of eyelid swelling and redness. But also general malaise and low grade fever are commonly reported. Among the classic signs of preseptal cellulitis are eyelid edema/erythema/warmth and fever. There are clinical keys that help us distinguish between preseptal and orbital cellulitis.

Incorrect options:

Preseptal cellulitis; eyelid edema and erythema, normal visual acuity, absence of proptosis, pupil with normal reaction to light, normal colour saturarion, normal conjunctiva and normal ocular movements.

Orbital cellulitis: eyelid edema and erythema, diminished visual acuity, proptosis is present, relative afferent pupillary defect may be present, reduced colour saturation, chemotic conjunctiva and reduced extraocular movements with pain elicited by these movements.

Cellulitis may extend to the cheek and forehead. Also, it is common to see an eyelid abscess associated with preseptal cellulitis, which may require incision and drainage.

Capillary hemangioma : A capillary hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor that can cause proptosis, but it is rare and less common than thyroid eye disease in adults. It is more often seen in infants and typically resolves on its own over time.

Key Takeaway: Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of proptosis in adults, particularly those with thyroid dysfunction. It leads to inflammation and swelling of the orbital tissues, causing the eyes to bulge.
